;;T;;世界上没有多少城市;地方政府推出了家庭音乐节。很少有像 ;芝加哥;。在一个阳光明媚的周日下午，各个种族、各个年龄段的人们涌入市中心的千禧公园，许多人手里拿着毯子、冷藏箱和折叠露营椅。然而，一位与会者显然不受欢迎。日落时分，头条新闻法利“Jackmaster”Funk，一位著名的芝加哥 ;DJ; 受邀成为一位特邀嘉宾。当市长布兰登·约翰逊慢跑上台时，响起了震耳欲聋的嘘声。 45 秒之内，他再次离开，他看似简短的信息——芝加哥是“世界上最伟大的城市”，不足以平息异议的喧嚣。

;

;对政客发出嘘声是风城悠久的传统（精明的人知道最好的出现时间是早点，在人群开始喝酒之前）。然而，去年在芝加哥教师工会的支持下意外赢得选举胜利的约翰逊已经异常不受欢迎。根据 4 月下旬（即他当选一年后）进行的一项民意调查，只有 9% 的芝加哥居民认为他的工作“高于平均水平”；大多数人说他的工作低于平均水平。即使在非白人选民（他的基础）中，低于平均水平的支持率与高于平均水平的支持率也是四比一。

;; A; ;GOOD MEMOIR; tells you a lot about a person, and even more about the times they lived in. A century of tyranny and war and finally, in some places, of democracy and peace has shaped the lives of all Europeans. Memoirists are among the best chroniclers of that history. Europe's ;Sturm und Drang; is like a recurring character in the autobiographies of people who themselves will never meet, except on the shelves of libraries and bookshops. As more than 350m people trudge to the polls on June 6th-9th to vote in European elections, what might they read to get a sense of their home, past and present?

;

;No one captures the sweep of history like Stefan Zweig. A popular writer in the early 20th century, he penned vivid biographies, of Magellan and Marie-Antoinette among others, which give the impression he had long been friends with them. From the 1930s the Austrian turned his attention to the fate of Europe and to himself.当他在《昨天的世界》的开篇章节中深入探讨过去时，这片大陆似乎处于良好的状态：人们多么渴望在 20 世纪早期的维也纳茨威格描述的地方度过一天，并跟随他一起走下去。当他拜访巴黎的奥古斯特·罗丹时。 But the mood quickly darkens as Zweig witnesses the continent's descent into madness. Soon the Nazis are burning his books (he was Jewish). He flees, ;eventually landing in Brazil;。 He posted the manuscript of this, his final book, to his publisher shortly before he and his wife committed suicide in February 1942. “The World of Yesterday” is an eerie, spellbinding read.
